statement.tex: \\ %text We will tell you that \[ \dfrac{\sin (x-a)}{\sin (x+a)} = \cos 2a -\sin 2a\cdot \dfrac{\cos\phi}{\sin\phi} \] But what is $\phi$ in terms of $x$? %
\\ %text Given $\dfrac{\sin (x-a)}{\sin (x+a)} = \cos 2a - \sin 2a\cdot\dfrac{\cos\phi}{\sin\phi}$, what will \[I = \int \dfrac{\sin (x-a)}{\sin (x+a)}\cdot dx\] evaluate to? %

reason.tex: \begin{align} &\phi= x + a \implies d\phi = dx \\ &\text{and }\dfrac{\sin (x-a)}{\sin (x+a)} = \cos 2a - \sin 2a\cdot\dfrac{\cos\phi}{\sin\phi} \\ &\therefore \int \dfrac{\sin (x-a)}{\sin (x+a)}dx = \int \left( \cos 2a -\sin 2a\frac{\cos\phi}{\sin\phi} \right) d\phi \\ &= \cos 2a \cdot\int d\phi - \underbrace{\sin 2a\cdot\int\dfrac{\cos\phi}{\sin\phi}d\phi}_{\sin\phi = z \implies \cos\phi\cdot d\phi = dz}\\ &= \cos 2a\cdot\phi - \sin 2a\cdot \log\vert \sin\phi\vert + C \\ &= \cos 2a \cdot (x+a) - \sin 2a\cdot\log\vert \sin (x+a)\vert + C \end{align}
